coredata.dc:title: Equations of state of mixtures of hard dumbbells
coredata.dc:creator: Enciso, E.
Gil, J.
Lago, S.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Two ways to predict pVT behavior of hard-dumbbell mixtures in the fluid region are proposed. These are adaptations of the hard convex body equation devised by Boublik and an extension of the first Barker-Henderson perturbation theory. Calculated compressibility factors show good agreement with the ideal mixing assumption and yield a useful equation of state.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 88, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 May 1982 EQUATIONS OF STATE OF MIXTURES OF HARD DUMBBELLS E. ENCISO, J. GIL Departamento de Qu[mica F[sica, Facultad de Ciencias Qu[micas, Universidad Complutense, Madrid-3, Spain and Instituto de Qu[mica F[sica R ocasolano, CSIC, Madrid, Spain and S. LAGO Insn'tut fiir Thermo- und Fluiddynamik, Ruhr Universitiit Bochum, 4630 Bochum, Federal Republic of Germany Received 27 November 1981 ; in final form 12 March 1982 Two ways to predict pVT behavior of hard-dumbbell mixtures in the fluid region are proposed. These are adaptations of the hard convex body equation devised by Boubl~ and an extension of the first Barker:Henderson perturbation theory. Calculated compressibility factors show good agreement with the ideal mixing assumption and yield a useful equation of state. 1. Introduction Fluids composed of hard dumbbells have been used as a reference system in the van der Waals description of pure non-associated diatomic fluids. Unfortunately, perturbation theories based upon angle-dependent reference systems require a fair number of properties of such a system. The equation of state must be known and along with it either the entire pair distribution function (PDF) [1 ] or the site-site correlation func- tion [2-4] (SSCF) is needed. On the other hand, the good results obtained for pure substances using SSCF led us to think that a mix- ture of hard dumbbells and spheres or hard dumbbells of different size could be a good reference system for mixtures of diatomic + monatomic or diatomic + di- atomic molecules. Certainly, it is difficult to obtain the PDF and only a few simulation results are avail- able [5]. Nevertheless, the recent numerical solution of the RISM equation for mixtures [6] allows the computation of SSCF with reasonable accuracy but thermodynamic properties obtained directly from a hard-site interaction model are very poor and the choice of a proper equation of state remains open. The purpose of this paper is to present and discuss extensions of prescriptions for hard convex bodies or hard spheres when they are applied to mixtures of hard dumbbells. Throughout the paper, we consider homo- nuclear hard dumbbells consisting of two hard fused spheres with the same diameter o and whose centers are separated by a distance L. When L* = L/o = 0, the dumbbell reduces to a hard sphere. Two equimolar mix- tures are studied. The first one is a mixture of hard spheres (L * = 0) and hard dumbbells with L* = 1. In the second case, the components have L* = 0.6 and L* = 0.2 2. Statement of the problem Aviram et al. [5] simulated an equimolar mixture with the same parameters as our second system. Monson and Rigby [7] found VE was small for mix- tures of hard spheres and hard spherocylinders. They calculated the equation of state of this mixture, as- suming ideal behaviour. Their resulting valueg agree very well with their own MC results. Now we extend this assumption to mixtures of dumbbells and hence- forth, refer to it as IM. The volumes of the pure com- ponents at each pressure were then calculated iterative- ly using the equation of state for pure hard dumbbells fitted to MC data by Tildesley et al. [8]. 0 009-2614/82/0000-0000/$ 02.75 © 1982 North-Holland 333 Volume 88, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICSLETTERS 7 May 1982 On the other hand, the BoublN equation of state works very well for mixtures of hard convex bodies (HCB) [9]. Further, Boubl~ and Nezbeda [10] have shown that a pure dumbbell fluid can be very well de- scribed by means of a HCB equation of state. There- fore, these ideas might be immediately extended to mixtures of dumbbells and we write p _ 1 + rs qs2(3-o) (1) okT 1-v 0(1 _v)2t" 90(1 _0)3 ' where r, s, v, q are geometric functionals of the mix- ture and are given as y=o~xiri, yi=Ri, Si, Vi, Qi, (2) Vi and Si are the volume and surface of the dumbbell modelling the component i, P is the number density and Qi = Ri, where Ri is (47r)-1 times the mean curva- ture integral of the circumscribed hard spherocylinder. One different way of tackling the problem comes from the treatment of hard-sphere mixtures. Recently, Kohler et al. [ 1 1 ], on the basis of an idea of Bellemans [12], investigated the thermodynamic properties of a pure hard-dumbbell fluid using perturbation theories with different choices of spherical reference system. They found the best approach is obtained when an averaged angle potential and a Barker-Henderson splitting of the potential (BH1) are used. Moreover, Freasier et al. [1 3] found the pressure of pure dumbbells can be very well fitted to simulation data using BH theory. We extend the abovementioned method to obtain thermodynamic properties of dumbbell mixtures. As usual, we relate the system properties to those of a hard-sphere system using a Taylor expansion in an in- verse steepness parameter a. Following Barker and Henderson, we define a modified potential function °(R12, 091, 092, dO, a) by exp [-~o(R 12,091,092)1 (3) =H(d0 + (RI2 dO)lot- d(091,092)), where H(x) = 0 for x < 0, and H(x) = 1 for x > 0 is the Heaviside step function. In (3) R 12 denotes the distance between the centers of mass of molecules 1 and 2 and 091 and 092 are the angular orientations with respect to the R12 axis. d(091, 092) is the distance between the centers when molecules 1 and 2 are in contact with orientations 09 1 and 6)2, respectively. Clearly, when a = 0, eq. (3) reproduces the hard- sphere potential, and when a = 1, the anisotropic po- tential of dumbbells is recovered. Expanding the Helmholtz free energy in powers of all the parameters, neglecting terms higher than the first, and putting finally aij = 1, we obtain for binary mixtures 2 2 o 0 (A -Ao)/NkT= 27r0 ~ ~ (dO)2 xixjgij(di]) i=1/'=1 X [(dii(091, 092)) - dO], (4) 0 0 where gi/(di/) are the contact values of the pair distri- bution function and ( ) denotes angular averaging: <d(09j, 092)> =fd(09~, 092) 0091 d092/fd091 d092- (5) Taking in (4) do = (dii) and di] =(dii + d//.)/2, terms in O~ii vanish and using thermodynamic relations, we can write the equation of state as p/flk T = (p/pk T)0 (6) + 4rr(dO2)2x i x2((d12) -- dO2) P ~)pgO2(dO2)fi)P, where (p/pkT)o is the compressibility factor of an ad- ditive hard-sphere mixture which has been calculated using the well-known equation of Mansoori et al. [14]. We choose the analytical equation proposed by Grundke and Henderson [15] forgO(dO) and (d)is evaluated by a numerical integration. When differences in shape be- tween the components are small, the contribution of the first-order perturbation term is very small and can be neglected. 3. Results and discussion The effect of molecular shape on the equation of state is depicted in fig. 1. Our results obey a similar rule for an equimolar mixture to the one suggested by Nezbeda et al. [16] for pure fluids, namely (p/pkT)EHS < (p/pkT)DB < (p/pkT)sc , where EHS denotes the equivalent hard-sphere mix- ture whose components have the same volume as dumbbells (DB) and SC means the mixture of sphero- cylinders with the same values Li as dumbbell molecules. 334 Volume 88, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 May 1982 I I I - / / I I 0.2 0.4 po3 I 0.6 Fig. 1. Equation of state for an equimolar mixture of hard spheres and hard molecules: ..... EHS as defined in the text; -- spherocylinders with L * = 1 ; --- HCB equation for dumbbells with L* = 1 ; • IM results. Values for hard spheres and spherocylinders have been calculated using the equations of Mansoori et al. [14] and Pavlicek et al. [17] respectively. The proposed approximations in eqs. (I)and (5) are compared with results from ideal mixing or from computer simulation, when available, for the two mix- tures considered in tables 1 and 2. This comparison gives good discernment about the ability of our ap- proaches to account for molecular anisotropy in p VT behaviour. Figs. 1 and 2 show that the HCB approxi- mation agrees very well with the assumption of ideal mixing of pure compounds at all densities..Also BH1 Table t Comparison of the compressibility z = p/pkT of an equimolar mixture of hard spheres and hard dumbbells of L* = 1 pa3 ZiM zpT ZHCB 0.1192 1.60 1.54 1.59 0.2908 3.28 3.14 3.25 0.3840 4.97 4.86 4.92 0.4412 6.49 6.48 6.43 0.5146 9.28 9.65 9.21 Table 2 As table 1 for an equimolar mixture of hard dumbbells of L* = 0.2 andL* = 0.6 po3 zMC ZlM zpT ZHCB 0.1 1.47 1.42 1.43 0.1224 1.56 1.54 1.55 0.2 2.22 2.07 2.09 0.3 3.39 3.18 3.12 3.14 0.3553 4.03 3.97 3.98 0.4 5.50 4.86 4.86 0.4540 6.31 6.29 6.24 0.5 9.34 7.85 7.91 7.79 0.5282 9.04 9.16 8.96 theory appears to be quite good, specially for small anisotropies. Since the HCB equation has proved to be very accurate for pure dumbbells and IM is a very good approximation for similar systems, results re- ported here represent a reliable basis. However, com- puter simulations of Aviram et al. [5] are much larger than the set of theories. It has been shown [8] that the extrapolation of SSCF in ref. [5] is wrong, due to a minor coding error in the program. Unfortunately, it is necessary for mixtures to make four extrapola- tions and the error is expected to be greater than for I I I / 8- 4 o I I I 0.3 0.4 0.5 po3 Fig. 2. Equation of state for an equimolar mixture of hard dumbbells with L* = 0.2 and L* = 0.6. zx MC results [5], • IM, -- BH1 theory, -- HCB equation of state. 335 Volume 88, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 May 1982 Table 3 Comparison of the second virial coefficients of equimolar mixtures obtained from cq. (7) and the results calculated from numerical integration B B B12 Xl = 1.0 x1 = 0.0 HCB calc. HCB calc. LI/L2 = 0.0/1.0 2.094 5.701 3.731 3.715 3.534 3.533 L1/L2 = 0.2/0.6 2.752 4.200 3.467 3.445 3.436 3.415 pure substances. Therefore we have taken direct simu- lations only as an upper bound. Second virial coefficients have been obtained for the mixture of dumbbells from numerical integration and HCB and are displayed in table 3. Results for the mixture of spheres and dumbbells can be analytically calculated and are also shown in table 3 for compari- son. For binary mixtures, the definition 2 B = ~ xixjBij (7) i,/=l has been used. Bii are the viriat coefficients for pure components as calculated by Isihara [ 18]. Theoretical values of B and B12 compare well with exact data and fall between those of pure substances. The remarkable agreement between all the con- sidered approximations indicates that they provide a fair prediction of the equation of state of hard- dumbbell mixtures. Moreover, the HCB equation makes an excellent estimate of B and the assumption of ideal mixing seems to offer a better description than original simulations [5]. Theories involving effective spherical diameters appear to be insensitive enough to the an- gular correlation functions of molecules with a high degree of anisotropy, at least in a first order of per- turbation. Finally, we have found BoublN's equations, originally devised for HCB mixtures or for pure hard dumbbells, also describe very well the equation of state of DB mixtures. We conclude that the HCB equation can be used as an excellent basis in the perturbation treatment of fluids with a hard- dumbbell mixture as a reference system. Acknowledgement One of us (SL) wishes to thank the Humboldt Foundation for a Humboldt fellowship and Professor F. Kohler for his hospitality. We are indebted to Dr. Lombardero and Mr. Martin of Instituto Rocasolano (CSIC) and Dr. Abascal of Complutense University for their help in the formulation of the ideas of this paper. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Two ways to predict pVT behavior of hard-dumbbell mixtures in the fluid region are proposed. These are adaptations of the hard convex body equation devised by Boublik and an extension of the first Barker-Henderson perturbation theory. Calculated compressibility factors show good agreement with the ideal mixing assumption and yield a useful equation of state.
